title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHOENIX (AP) — They came to see Charles Barkley and Hakeem Olajuwon, two titans colliding in the desert. They left having witnessed the breathtaking, unstoppable ascent of a single star who rendered all others obsolete.

In a performance for the ages, the Houston Rockets’ Clyde Drexler dropped a staggering 41 points, carving up the Phoenix Suns with a breathtaking offensive display. Yet, in a cruel twist of basketball fate, his historic individual effort was all for naught as the Suns, powered by a balanced and relentless attack, prevailed 109-96.

Drexler was a man possessed, a blur of motion and precision. Every spin, every drive, every pull-up jumper was a brushstroke in a masterpiece. He sliced through the Phoenix defense at will, his 41 points a monument to his skill and determination. On any other night, such a herculean effort would have single-handedly secured victory.

But the Suns had a different script in mind. They countered Drexler’s solo symphony with a chorus of contributors. Kevin Johnson orchestrated the offense with 20 points, while Wesley Person stretched the floor, draining critical three-pointers on his way to 21 points. The bedrock of their victory, however, was a dominant 50-38 rebounding advantage, with Hot Rod Williams (15 rebounds) and Barkley (13 rebounds) controlling the glass and denying Houston second chances.

While Drexler authored a night he will never forget, the Suns authored the final, decisive chapter. They weathered the superstar’ storm, shared the ball, and ground down the Rockets with collective force, turning a legendary individual performance into a heartbreaking footnote on the final scoreboard.
